nodes.text: Intergenerational income mobility in the United States varies substantially across geographic areas and this geographic variation helps explain who attains economic opportunity

Method: Constructed parent-child income links and mobility measures using deidentified federal income tax records (population data) covering >40 million children and their parents (1996–2012); assign children to commuting zones (CZs) where they grew up using parent ZIP when child first claimed as dependent

Measurement choice: rank-rank specification (children and parents ranked in national distributions) provides a stable, nearly linear summary of parent-child association; canonical log-log IGE is unstable and sensitive to zeros and nonlinearities

National result: the rank-rank slope is 0.341 (i.e., a 10 percentile increase in parent rank is associated with a 3.41 percentile increase in child rank); college attendance and teen birth rates are linearly related to parent rank

Evidence on log-log IGE: canonical IGE estimates vary widely (0.26–0.70) depending on sample and treatment of zeros; dollar-weighted IGE (Mitnik et al.) and other adjustments yield closer values but rank-rank preferred for robustness

Spatial variation: large CZ-level heterogeneity in relative and absolute mobility; example CZs: probability of rising from bottom to top quintile ranges from 4.4% in Charlotte to 12.9% in San Jose; absolute upward mobility r25 ranges from 35.8 (Charlotte) to 46.2 (Salt Lake City) among largest CZs

Claim: Spatial variation in mobility is correlated with observable CZ characteristics but these correlations are not causal proofs; the publicly released CZ, MSA, and county mobility statistics can facilitate causal research

Evidence on timing/robustness: rank-rank estimates stabilize by child age ~30; using 5-year parent income averages largely removes attenuation bias; results robust to alternative income definitions, price-adjustments, and growth adjustments

Method detail: summarize CZ-level conditional expectation of child rank given parent rank by linear regression Ric = alpha_c + beta_c Pic where beta_c is relative mobility and rpc = alpha_c + beta_c p is CZ absolute mobility at parent percentile p (focus r25)

National transition matrix: quintile transition shows 7.5% of children from national bottom quintile reach top quintile; US rank-rank slope is larger than Denmark and Canada (US ~0.34 vs Denmark ~0.18, Canada ~0.17)

Observation: Absolute and relative mobility are highly correlated across CZs (unweighted corr ~ -0.68 between rank-rank slope and r25) and differences in mobility matter most for children from low-income families (spatial effects pivot around ~85th parent percentile)

Intermediate outcomes vary with geography: CZ-level gradients for college attendance, college quality, and teenage birth by parent rank mirror income mobility patterns, implying causal factors operate while children are growing up

Empirical correlates: five CZ-level factors strongly correlated with lower upward mobility are (i) greater residential segregation (esp. segregation of poverty), (ii) greater income inequality among the bottom 99% (Gini bottom99), (iii) worse K-12 school outputs (test scores, dropouts adjusted for income), (iv) lower social capital, and (v) weaker family stability (higher single-parent share)

Evidence on segregation and access: racial segregation and income segregation negatively correlated with r25 (e.g., segregation of poverty strongly negative); shorter commutes (less spatial mismatch) positively correlated with mobility; segregation of affluence and top 1% shares weakly correlated

Evidence on inequality and schools: CZ Gini (bottom 99%) negatively correlated with mobility and size of middle class positively correlated; high-school test-score and dropout residuals (income-adjusted) positively correlated with mobility; top 1% income share shows little correlation

Multivariate finding and caveat: in multivariable regressions the five factors together explain a large share of cross-CZ variance in mobility and remain predictive with state fixed effects, but these associations are not causal due to endogeneity and measurement error

Conclusion: mobility is a local problem amenable to place-based investigation; results motivate causal follow-ups (e.g., studying moves across areas by families) rather than interpreting correlations as definitive causal mechanisms
